thread.title: Deni Ute Muster an outback eye-opener
thread.title_full: Deni Ute Muster an outback eye-opener

author: John Bisset
title: Deni Ute Muster an outback eye-opener
text:
Deni Ute Muster an outback eye-opener JOHN BISSET Last updated 07:32, October 24 2015 JOHN BISSET/FAIRFAX NZ 
17 annual Deniliquin Ute Muster. 
Need an exciting event to add to your bucket list? I'd recommend the Deni Ute Muster in New South Wales. 
It's Australia's biggest rural festival. This year 18,000 campers, 5988 utes, 5000 camper trailers, tents and mobile homes turned up for the two-day event. 
We attended the 17th annual Muster earlier this month during a return road trip from Sydney to Deniliquin. JOHN BISSET/FAIRFAX NZ JOHN BISSET/FAIRFAX NZ JOHN BISSET/FAIRFAX NZ JOHN BISSET/FAIRFAX NZ JOHN BISSET/FAIRFAX NZ JOHN BISSET/FAIRFAX NZ JOHN BISSET/FAIRFAX NZ JOHN BISSET/FAIRFAX NZ JOHN BISSET/FAIRFAX NZ JOHN BISSET/FAIRFAX NZ JOHN BISSET/FAIRFAX NZ JOHN BISSET/FAIRFAX NZ John Bisset JOHN BISSET/FAIRFAXNZ JOHN BISSET/FAIRFAX NZ JOHN BISSET/FAIRFAX NZ JOHN BISSET/FAIRFAX NZ 
Cold Chisel entertains during the evening. 
The world record attempt for the most blue singlets. 
Aerial view of the Deni Ute Muster. 
Jesse Walsh, Shannon Taylor, Teagan Thorburn and Linzy Pattison. 
Jeremy Pelns competes in the Circle work competition. 
Lee Kernaghan entertains the crowd. 
Jill and Gavin Faravoni relax in the afternoon sun. 
Cold Chisel concert. 
Aerial view of the Deni Ute Muster at Deniliquin New South Wales. 
Kaleigh Welch competes in the Circle Work competition. 
Jimmy Barnes of Cold Chisel entertains the crowd. 
The crowd enjoys the Cold Chisel concert. 
Sisters Celia and Gemma O'Kane came all the way from Yarrawonga Victoria with their Holden ute. 
One of the older utes was a 1947 Chev belonging to Drew Bennett. 
Dancing the day away are from left, Steve Dent, Dyland Kelly, Jordan Dalton and Ben Thomson. 
Jarryd Gazelle of Gisborne Victoria with his 2002 VU Commodore that won the Circle work competition. 1 of 17 « Previous « Previous Next » Next » 
The mass meeting of fellow minded ute lovers was mind-blowing. Acres of vehicles were lined up in rows that went on for as far as the eye could see. Hundreds of barbecues and drum fires were scattered between all types of shelters for their overnight stays. We were fortunate to have a rent-a-tent complete with stretcher, a soft pillow and light – palatial – compared to sleeping on the back of a ute I thought. 
There were several camping options the first being the ute paddock. No caravans or trailers are permitted there. It was soon obvious that this area was, party central. Come twilight it was all go, music, and bonfires, and younger ones dancing on the back of their utes (some even had dancing poles) were having a ball. 
Also close to this area was the non-ute paddock, where you could tent, caravan or sleep in your car. JOHN BISSET/FAIRFAX NZ 
Aerial view of the Deni Ute Muster at Deniliquin New South Wales. 
If you are a bit older like myself and needed a bit of sleep, then the family camping area was the place to be with noise restrictions were in place. It was a great area to be especially if you had children. 
When we arrived at the rally site on Friday afternoon at 4pm, it was still 34 degrees Celsius. I couldn't believe some of our Aussie neighbours were still wearing jeans. 
Our tent was supplied and set up, so we explored the rally site. Talk about huge – we seemed to walk forever but never managed to get around all the isles of utes and campers. 
A helicopter flight over the festival grounds the next day showed the enormity of the event. I had to ask the pilot to keep flying away from the site so I could get the whole area in my viewfinder. Ad Feedback 
We awoke on Saturday to typical Aussie weather, a cloudless blue sky and 30C plus. There was no shortage of entertainment during the day. 
Ute barrel racing was popular, with large crowds lining the banks. Two utes race around 44 gal drums in the dust laden arena, with the winner moving on to the next race, at times all you could see were clouds of dust. 
Most of those entrants also competed in the Circle Work Championship where drivers showcased their skills of drifting, donuts and the execution of figure eights. 
Rodeo bull riding also drew a huge crowd who watched as cowboys were sent flying through the air and eating red Aussie dirt. 
Other events during the day included, motoX stunt riding, whip cracking competitions and even a dunny building competition. The Holden Grunt Off had teams of men and woman dragging a Holden ute 40 metre, competing for the fastest time. 
The blue singlet, world record attempt was at high noon. Entrants collected an official count sticker before congregating near the main stage. 
Exactly 3959 people turned out wearing their blue singlets in a sweltering 34C to set another world record by 35C. 
Water tankers provided much needed drinking water during the heat of the day, with one spraying jets of water into the air to the delight of many of the overheated crowd. 
Graham Brown from The Oaks in NSW is $10,000 better off after winning Ute of the Year with his 1982 Toyota Landcruiser. Brown spent more than $100,000 and 12 years completing the project. 
Lots of showers and portaloos were scattered around the venue; however, there were often long queues to get into one. 
Cold Chisel, Lee Kernaghan, Birds of Tokyo, The Wolf Brothers, Adam Brand and the Sunny Cowgirls were just some of the bands that had the crowd rocking into the early hours of the morning. 
Music echoed across the campsite at night, providing a real party atmosphere. When things got quiet, there was no shortage of ute owners redlining their engines and piercing the night air with a screaming V8. 
It was certainly an eye-opening experience and something worth seeing. I'm definitely keen to go again. 
John Bisset travelled as a guest of Destination New South Wales . - Stuff
